[[Beanpot (ice hockey)|Beanpot Championship]], W 6-5 (OT) vs. [[Harvard Crimson|Harvard]] |prevseason = [[2006â07 Boston College Eagles men's ice hockey season|2006-07]] |nextseason = [[2008â09 Boston College Eagles men's ice hockey season|2008-09]] |headerstyle = background:#8B0000; color:#F0E68C; |labelstyle = background:#eeeeee; }} The '''2007-2008 Boston College Eagles men's ice hockey team''' represented [[Boston College]] in the 2007-2008 college hockey season. The team was coached by [[Jerry York]], '67, his fourteenth season behind the bench at Boston College. The Eagles played their home games at [[Conte Forum|Kelley Rink]] on the campus of Boston College, and competed in [[Hockey East]]. Having lost in the previous season's national championship to [[Michigan State Spartans men's ice hockey|Michigan State]], Boston College made its third consecutive appearance in the title game and defeated [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish men's ice hockey|Notre Dame]] 4-1 in the [[2008 NCAA Division I Men's Ice Hockey Tournament|2010 Frozen Four]] Championship Game, earning the school's third national championship and first since 2001. The Eagles defeated [[Minnesota Golden Gophers men's ice hockey|Minnesota]] and [[Miami RedHawks men's ice hockey|Miami (OH)]] in the Northeast Regional in [[Worcester, MA|Worcester]], earning them a berth in the Frozen Four to be played at the [[Pepsi Center]] in [[Denver]]. BC defeated [[North Dakota Fighting Sioux men's ice hockey|North Dakota]] 6-1 in the national semifinal before taking on the Irish in championship game. The Eagles finished fourth in the 2007-2008 Hockey East Regular Season, which was good enough for the last home-ice spot in the Hockey East playoffs. After sweeping the quarterfinal series against [[Providence Friars|Providence]], the Eagles met regular-season champion [[New Hampshire Wildcats|New Hampshire]] in the conference semifinals. After trailing early on, the Eagles mounted a come back and eventually beat UNH on a [[Benn Ferriero]] goal early in the third overtime. BC went on to defeat [[Vermont Catamounts men's ice hockey|Vermont]] in the championship game 4-0 for the school's eighth Hockey East tournament championship. BC also won the 56th Annual [[Beanpot (ice hockey)|Beanpot Tournament]]. After defeating defending champions [[Boston University Terriers men's ice hockey|Boston University]] 4-3 in overtime thanks to a [[Nathan Gerbe]] goal, the Eagles went on to defeat [[Harvard Crimson|Harvard]] 6-5 in overtime on a goal by freshman defenseman [[Nick Petrecki]]. This was BC's 14th Beanpot title and first since 2004. Junior forward [[Nathan Gerbe]], who led the nation in scoring, narrowly missed out on winning the [[Hobey Baker Memorial Award|Hobey Baker Award]].
